comment.body: I think I found a solution for this problem. I have to bump the minimum to 1.5 to use a better solution with little impact on compatibility.

pull_request.title: Allow Linux and MacOs to consume this wrapper without issues
pull_request.body:
This pull request contains codes that allow Linux and macOS to consume this wrapper.

The changes are:
1. Addition of Lib_OQS_KEM_* and Lib_OQS_SIG_* methods for both Linux and macOS. (They are essentially pointed to the original signature in DllImport)
2. Changed target frameworks to netstandard1.2 and netstandard2.0 allowing different version of .Net Core and .Net framework version to use this library. (netstandard1.2 is added for compatibility with the existing test case for netcoreapp1.1)
3. Removed prebuild event for all projects except test case to allow other OS to execute the new dotnet cli commands.
4. Addition of some useful scripts that can be used for reference for building this project. (Consist of windows and macOS variants)

#2 #10

comment.body: Can save bandwidth by doing `git clone --single-branch`. Or could just download the OpenSSL release .tar.gz from their website.

pull_request.title: Updates to this repository.
pull_request.body:
Updated this repository as per discussions with @dstebila and @baentsch. 

I've also added CMake and ninja to the CI environments, and once the environments are in use, I'll update the CI scripts in my CMake PR.

comment.body: It was downloading the `.tar.gz` before, but I was running into build errors involving `zlib`, even with the `no-comp` option passed to `./config`. For now I just decided to switch to the source, but I'll add a TODO to look into this apparent discrepancy.

pull_request.title: Updates to this repository.

Updated this repository as per discussions with @dstebila and @baentsch. 

I've also added CMake and ninja to the CI environments, and once the environments are in use, I'll update the CI scripts in my CMake PR.

comment.body: I have found out that it actually prepend "lib" on library names on Linux and macOS. Oh well, I have undo them and just edit the DllImport constant to "oqs".

pull_request.title: Allow Linux and MacOs to consume this wrapper without issues
pull_request.body:
This pull request contains codes that allow Linux and macOS to consume this wrapper.

The changes are: (Updated)

1. ~~Addition of Lib_OQS_KEM_* and Lib_OQS_SIG_* methods for both Linux and macOS. (They are essentially pointed to the original signature in DllImport)~~
[Update] I have found out that DllImport actually prepend "lib" into library names for linux and macOS. However, they have to be exact as in "liboqs.so" is not equals to "liboqs.so.0.0.0" As a result, the changes would just be [DllImport("oqs")] instead.

2. Changed target frameworks to netstandard1.2 and netstandard2.0 allowing different version of .Net Core and .Net framework version to use this library. (netstandard1.2 is added for compatibility with the existing test case for netcoreapp1.1)

3. Removed prebuild event for all projects except test case to allow other OS to execute the new dotnet cli commands.

4. Addition of some useful scripts that can be used for reference for building this project. (Consist of Windows, Linux and macOS variants)

5. Updated documentation in README.md to have a slightly more verbose information on how to build the sample application and the wrapper.

Sample Application Tested on:
- [x] Windows 10
- [x] Linux (Ubuntu 18.04 LTS)
- [x] macOS (Mojave)

Relevant issues: #2 #10
